body: IPG 359.
I've included more tests. @mdeuser, please take another look.

@rabbah - Regarding docs, the docs have not been updated to reflect the addition of the Go CLI (we're still rolling out our tests and fixing "blocking" issues).  I'll create an issue to make sure the docs are updated when we are ready to make this CLI officially available.

@mdeuser, added tests. Please take another look.

Note that when you create a trigger with a feed, the parameters are passed to the feed and not stored on the trigger - because usually the parameters you are passing to the feed include credentials or other secrets that are only needed to negotiate with the event source. If those parameters are stored as parameters of the trigger, then they are available to the action that is invoked via a rule - this may not be desired.

What's proposed in 471 is that the feed may choose to store certain parameters on the trigger - and we may want to store these in a different field that parameters (since they are related to the life cycle management of the feed).

> To make matters more "interesting", the client doesn't hang if you wait "long enough" between 2. and 3. (experimental fiddling suggests ~1mn, could be less).

Indeed - but then issue yet another `wsk list` and it will hang.

A namespace for activations should be ignored as all activations for a subject go to one namespace.

The namespace on activation list should be ignored - all activations are stored in the default namespace for a subject. This is true for activation poll as well. If you pass the namespace to the API call you will get back an empty list. Suggest either disabling the feature in the cli, generating a warning, or masking it (I think the Python cli is doing the last of these).

IPG 396.

The revision to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/645#issuecomment-232534948 as discussed with @mbehrendt is to distinguish between `200` + `statusMessage == success` and `200` + `statusMessage != success` using a `20x` status code with `207` suggested as an alternative.

The rational for the disambiguation, in the absence of a header, it makes for easier analysis of request/response using network debugging and tracing tools vs. parsing a json object (the body) to classify success vs error.

I suggested `207` which loosely fits into the whisk activation response: there is a `status` field in the activation record that indicates success or one of several classes of failures [1] even though `207` was proposed for a different purpose [2].

[1] http://www.restpatterns.org/HTTP_Status_Codes/207_-_Multi-Status
[2] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4918#section-13

Summary of subsequent discussion with @mbehrendt on this topic:
1. anonymous rule does not necessarily mean unnamed - the system may generate a name for the rule; by making the rule implicitly named, the trigger-action mapping should be unique (unless explicitly named).
2. rather than introduce two ways of creating rules (one via `wsk rule create` and another via `wsk trigger associate`) there will be only one way to create a rule (named or unnamed) and it will be via `wsk rule create` (with optional rule name); this avoids introducing new terminology and non-orthogonal mechanisms for doing the same thing.
3. to save a step for the user, creating a rule will enable it by default (similarly deleting a rule [that is not named] should disable it by default).
4. we may be able to implement these implicitly named rules via the CLI (or UI) - entirely on the client initially with light additive changes to the rules API (rules list should provide trigger/action details and possibly allow filtering by trigger name).
5. we will measure the popularity of unnamed vs named rules and learn from the data.
6. (somewhat related), rules should allow for parameters that may be merged with trigger payloads before passing to action invocations.
Closing for now, evaluation of different solutions pending.

My branch [api-v2-poc](https://github.com/psuter/openwhisk/tree/api-v2-poc) may give a head start to the person who will do this.

For this particular capability addressed by this issue, the Go command line package behaves a bit differently than the Python command line parser.  In particular, when a command line argument (i.e. `--apihost`) is defined against the root command and sub-commands, the sub-command definition "wins".

The Go `wsk` command defines `--apihost`, `--auth` and `--apiversion` flags that each take a string argument; the Go `wsk property get` command defines the same flags; however, these flags are boolean switches and do not take string arguments.  When the command arguments are merged, it appears that the final command's definition (`get` in this scenario) will override any previous argument definitions having the same name.

Consequently, as this issue describes, the Go CLI behavior will differ from the Python CLI for this scenario.  While a bit contrived, here's a silly example that shows the described behavior.

```
>wsk property get --apihost
whisk API host           openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net
>wsk --apihost openwhisk.stage1.ng.bluemix.net property get --apihost
whisk API host           openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net
```

One solution may be to have two commands - one command that manages CLI configuration and another command that obtains whisk server settings.

@rabbah, if a namespace is provided for activation list or poll, that namespace is passed via an &name argument to the backend. Currently, this behavior occurs for both CLIs.

Ex: `GET https://address/api/v1/namespaces/_/activations?docs=true&skip=0&limit=0&name=whisk.system`
Are you suggesting to get rid of the &name parameter from the URL?

@houshengbo - Per @rabbah 's comment above, the packages you want to access reside in a separate namespace, `whisk.system` which is not your default namespace.  The CLI can be configured with a default namespace `wsk property set --namespace NAME`; all subsequent CLI commands will default to that namespace.  Use `wsk property get --namespace` to see your current default namespace configuration.  If you want to access another namespace while retaining the default namespace configuration, the target entity must include the target namespace (i.e. `/whisk.system/weather` is the qualified name of the weather package).

Entities in have access control protection via --auth key and the entity's public(shared)/private setting.  So even though you know the namespace, you might not have access to a particular entity in that namespace.  Currently, this access control implementation has issues per the following conversation I had with @rabbah.

```
Mark Deuser [8:17 AM]  
ah.. `wsk package list /whisk.system` does work
are the /whisk.system entities shared?
maybe that's where i'm confused.. does a `public` entity give read rights (i.e. list, copy) ?
packages, actions, triggers, and rules can all be created as `public`

Rodric Rabbah [8:24 AM]  
Yeah that's misleading we have defects to address
Only carries meaning on a package today
```

So, at the moment, the public/private setting is only applicable to packages right now; this means that even though a non-package entity in another namespace may be configured as `public (shared)`, it won't be directly accessible via the CLI.  To have that access to that entity, you will need to supply the namespace's auth key.

@rabbah - Feel free to confirm and/or correct.

@jeremiaswerner @mbehrendt   A simple use case for disk is our own image processing demo which writes the image to a temporary file before invoking image magic.

@domdom82  I agree that 1.12 is the first reasonable thing to switch to.  I'll try to do a parallelism study soon so we have numbers.  If 1.12 is at least as good as 1.11, then we should proceed on performance grounds.   That leaves stability testing which we can only confirm by testing at scale in the system as local and small scale tests historically cannot flush these out.

You omitted the leading slash on the namespace - that's why you're seeing the `name` query parameter in the URL.

`wsk activation list /whisk.system` vs `wsk activation list whisk.system` the latter filters activations for the given entity name.

My comment - to clarify - means that if you have a default namespace `/A` and a second namespace `/A_dev`, doing this `wsk activation list /A_dev` will yield `[]` because all activations for the same subject are in the default namespace `/A`. If you don't own the namespace then you won't be authorized for it, of course.
